occurrences.line_text: And on their Paynim foes auenge their ranckled ire.
Now ranckleth in this same fraile fleshly mould,
Ne might his ranckling paine with patience be appeasd.
Their ranckling wounds, & euery day them duely drest.
And ranckling inward with vnruly stounds,
Made all of rusty yron, ranckling sore,
And with strong hand their fruitfull rancknes did deface.
In endlesse rancks along enraunged were,
Set by it selfe, and ranckt in comely rew:
Whilome doth rancle in my riuen brest,
Had left, now gan afresh to rancle sore,
As when two Bores with rancling malice met,
But he enrag'd with rancor, nothing heares.
Without fell rancor, or fond gealosie;
So flam'd his eyne with rage and rancorous yre:
Cruell Reuenge, and rancorous Despight,
A filthy bloud, or humour rancorous,
His rancorous despight did not releasse,
Then fraught with rancour, and engorged ire,
With deadly rancour he enraunged fond,
Her gracious words their rancour did appall,
Yet yield he would not, nor his rancour slacke.
Happy, who can abstaine, when Rancour rife
His honour staines with rancour and despight,
When rancour doth with rage him once engore,
For vile disdaine and rancour, which did gnaw
And cruell rancour dim'd his valorous
Vile rancour to auoid, and cruell surquedrie.
Their direfull rancour rather did encreasse;
Vile rancour their rude harts had fild with such despight.
They gan abate the rancour of their rage,
For she was stuft with rancour and despight
Burning with inward rancour and despight,
Ne euer shewed signe of rancour or of iarre.
Bitter despight, with rancours rusty knife,
But as a blindfold Bull at randon fares,
The land for sea, at randon there to raunge:
The gentle Lady, loose at randon left,
With which he shot at randon, when him list,
There might ye see loose steeds at randon ronne,
Ne rov'd at randon after gazers guyse,
So now all range, and doe at randon roue
As thing at randon left, to whom he list.
Doth runne at randon, and with furious bit
And with sharpe reasons rang her such a pele,
To range the field, and victorlike to raine,
So now all range, and doe at randon roue
And range through all the wood, where so he wist
Who all this while at will did range and raine,
That it his ranging fancie did refraine,
By which few crooked sallowes grew in ranke:
Of many yron hammers beating ranke,
With diuers trees, enrang'd in euen rankes;
And festring sore did rankle yet within,
But closely rankled vnder th'orifis:
She saw could ease his rankling maladie,
And also for the sharpnesse of her rankling wound.
Then forth they ranne like two amazed deare,
The whiles her husband ranne with sory haste,
And ranne into her louers armes right fast;
In which he swam, and ranne to his redresse.
And with their ryder ranne perforce away:
Streight downe she ranne, like an enraged cow,
Vnto the wyld wood ranne, her dolours to deplore.
Which by the ransack of that peece they should attaine.
Which as a victour proud, gan ransack fast
And rather do not ransack all, and him selfe kill?
Who it to rob and ransacke did intend.
Then gan they ransacke that same Castle strong,
And ransacke all their dennes from most to least,
Since which, with sundrie spoiles she hath beene ransacked.
And win rich spoile of ransackt chastetee.
And ransackt Greece well tryde, whe[n] they were wroth;
And ransackt all her veines with passion entire.
Ransackt the world, and in the wofull harts
Great cities ransackt, and strong castles rast,
For ransome leauing him the late borne childe;
(Said he) then ransome of the richest knight,
Eftsoones one of those villeins him did rap
But with my speare vpon the shield did rap,
For he liu'd all on rauin and on rape
Paridell rapeth Hellenore:
And rapt with whirling wheeles, inflames the skyen,
Whose circled waters rapt with whirling sway,
Amoret rapt by greedie lust
The Prince halfe rapt, began on her to dote:
Are rapt with wonder, and with rare affright.
So was this Souldan rapt and all to rent,
That he was rapt with double rauishment,
And rapt with pleasaunce, wist not what to weene;
Sends to my doubtfull eares these speaches rare,
The God himselfe vewing that mirrhour rare,
He wondred at her wisedome heauenly rare,
That shynd, like twinkling stars, with stons most pretious rare.
Where store they found of all, that dainty was and rare.
Of tydings strange, and of aduentures rare:
Of milde demeanure, and rare courtesie,
Of wondrous beauty, and of bountie rare,
And alwayes led, to her with reuerence rare
And rauished with rare impression in his sprite.
He shewd that day, and rare ensample made,
And rare perfection in mortalitie,
He was a man of rare redoubted might,
The antique shapes of kings and kesars straunge & rare.
Whenas those knights beheld, with rare delight,
And let him heare some part of their rare melody.
So fashioned a Porch with rare deuice,
In th'one her rule, in th'other her rare chastitee.
A worke of rare deuice, and wondrous wit.
And of rare beautie, sauing that askaunce
Nought wanted there, that dainty was and rare;
Tho her auizing of the vertues rare,
As for pure chastitie and vertue rare,
In stedfast chastitie and vertue rare,
Many Restoratiues of vertues rare,
Of bountie, and of beautie, and all vertues rare.
Need teacheth her this lesson hard and rare,
Which with rare light his bote did beautifie,
That the rare sweetnesse of the melody
Of rare aspect, and beautie without peare;
Full many great calamities and rare
Sith now of dayes such temperance is rare
That with the sweetnesse of her rare delight,
Abounding all with delices most rare,
But much more rare and pretious to esteeme,
That of a fishes shell was wrought with rare delight.
Was toucht with soft remorse and pitty rare;
The royall banquets, and the rare delights,
Are rapt with wonder, and with rare affright.
With all deare delices and rare delights,
Or could be fram'd by workmans rare deuice;
Yet did appeare rare beautie in her face,
And rare in-sight, hard matters to reuele;
Royall examples of her mercies rare,
Who gaue him roiall giftes and riches rare,
That I nigh rauisht with rare thoughts delight,
For the rare hope which in his yeares appear'd,
With diuers flowres distinct with rare delight,
And manhood rare, but terrible and stearne
But in a Iacket quilted richly rare,
And markt her rare demeanure, which him seemed
Ne ought in all that world of beauties rare,
Diuine resemblaunce, beauty soueraine rare,
And also of the place, whose pleasures rare
To cherish her with all things choice and rare;
In the base blood of such a rascall crew;
But lightly rased her soft silken skin,
Least suddaine mischiefe ye too rash prouoke:
And rash misweening doe thy hart remoue:
Which hearing his rash Syre, began to rend
Thee, foolish man, so rash a doome to giue?
That could haue dazd the rash beholders sight,
Himselfe in streighter bandes too rash implyes,
Which he by many rash aduentures wan,
That quite bereau'd the rash beholders sight:
As through the flouring forrest rash she fled,
And rash Occasion makes vnquiet life.
T'auoide the rash assault and wrathfull stowre
But rash Pyrrochles varlet, Atin hight,
I read thee rash, and heedlesse of thy selfe,
That was Ambition, rash desire to sty,
The rash reuengers heat. Words well dispost
And suffred rash Pyrrochles wast his idle might.
Threatning vnheedie wrecke and rash decay,
So th'other did mens rash desires apall,
From rash reuenge, she had him surely slaine,
And pardon simple man, that rash did him displease.
And shields did share, & mailes did rash, and helmes did hew.
And rash prouoking perils all about,
Als of his owne rash hand one wound was to be seene.
With misregard, that some rash witted wight,
And pardon crau'd for his so rash assault,
Rashing off helmes, and ryuing plates a sonder,
The angry beasts not rashly to despise,
With him in bloudie armes they rashly did debate.
Well weeting trew, what she had rashly told;
Rashly out of their rouzed couches sprong,
None of them rashly durst to her approch,
Ne durst aduenture rashly in to wend,
That we thus rashly through thy darkesome dore,
Sir knight, that doest thy voyage rashly make
Where ill became him, rashly would haue thrust,
The wicked weapon rashly he did wrest,
And made repent, that he had rashly lusted
As men awaked rashly out of dreme,
If he too rashly to his charet drew,
And valiant knights doe rashly enterprize,
Who rashly sought that, which I mote not see.
Through vnaduized rashnesse woxen wood;
And when him list the raskall routes appall,
And after, all the raskall many ran,
Sought with his raskall routs t'enclose them round,
And with his sword disperst the raskall flockes,
And mingled with the raskall rablement,
And none appear'd of all that raskall rout,
A raskall rout, with weapons rudely dight.
The raskall manie soone they ouerthrew,
That raskall many with vnpittied spoyle;
Was fowly ra'st, that none the signes might see;
And quite from of th'earth their memory be rast?
Great cities ransackt, and strong castles rast,
Streight gan he him reuile, and bitter rate,
As if he did a dogge to kenell rate,
The one right feeble through the euill rate
No words may rate, nor rigour him remoue
Thus sate they all a round in seemely rate:
And to reuile, and rate, and recreant call,
Ne spareth he most learned wits to rate,
As rated Spaniell takes his burden vp for feare.
And him reuil'd, and rated, and disdayned,
Too rathe cut off by practise criminall
That rather death desire, then such despight.
But through his boldnesse rather feare did reach,
And giues not rather cause it to forsake?
With many rather for to go astray,
To me sad mayd, or rather widow sad,
There did I find, or rather I was found
Rather then matter of iust memory,
Or rather would, O would it so had chaunst,
But me behoueth rather to vpbrayd,
Of anguish, rather then of crime hath beene,
Gan smyle on them, that rather ought to weepe,
In daunger rather to be drent, then brent?
Do rather choose my flitting houres to spend,
But rather fowler seemed to the eye;
Or rather worthy of great Phoebus rote,
But rather y Scuith gogh, signe of sad crueltee.
Rather then fly, or be captiu'd her selfe she slew.
Rather for pleasure, then for battery or fight.
But th'other rather higher did arise,
And was arayd, or rather disarayd,
But rather shewd more white, if more might bee:
Die rather would he, then endure that same.
Their direfull rancour rather did encreasse;
But rather doth my helpelesse griefe augment.
Dye rather, dye, then so disloyally
Dye rather, dy, then euer loue disloyally.
Dye rather, dye, and dying do her serue,
Dye rather, dye, then euer from her seruice swerue.
Dye rather, dye, then euer so faire loue forsake.
But rather chose to dye for sorrow great,
Rather then of the tyrant to be caught:
But rather ioyd to be, then seemen sich:
For misery craues rather mercie, then repriefe.
Die had she rather in tormenting griefe,
And rather do not ransack all, and him selfe kill?
That durst not barke; and rather had he dy,
And meant to rauish her, that rather had to dy.
Rather let try extremities of chaunce,
But rather stird to cruell enmity,
And rather die then Ladies cause release.
But rather ought in friendship for her sake
That with thy meaning so I may the rather meete.
But rather will reserue it for a Canto new.
And doe not rather wish them soone expire,
But rather stird to vengeance and despight,
Ne followd on so fast, but rather sought
Who would not to this vertue rather yeeld his voice?
And rather stird by his discordfull Dame,
But boastfull Braggadocchio rather chose,
For very gall, that rather wholly dead
That rather seemes, sith knowen armes ye shonne.
And rather then my loue abandon so,
So had I rather to be thrall, then free;
But rather gan in troubled mind deuize,
But rather of his hand besought to die.
And rather chose his challenge off to breake,
And rather guilty chose him selfe to yield.
Did yield, she rather should with him remaine
And rather then his loue should suffer paine,
But rather in them kindled choler new.
But rather stroue extremities to way,
And rather had to lose, then trie in armes his right.
I rather chose to die in liues despight,
Rather then see her people spoiled quight,
Die rather would he in penurious paine,
But rather how she mote him faster tye.
Her rather reade his meaning, then him selfe it spake.
Well shot in yeares he seem'd, and rather bent
Who though desirous rather to rest mute,
Yet rather then she kindnesse would despize,
Now will ye sleepe? ah wake, and rather weepe,
But rather let in stead thereof to fall
Dye rather, then doe ought, that mote dishonour yield.
But rather more enrag'd for those words sake;
But rather did more chearefull seeme therefore.
Rather then let my selfe of wight be stroken,
He rather should haue taken vp behind.
Him charge with guilt, but rather doe quite clame:
The rather since that fortune hath this day
But rather wish, that some more noble hire,
That rather seem'd the conquest of his might,
And rather needed to be disciplinde
That rather needes wise read and discipline,
Yet rather counseld him contrarywize,
And rather did the more her beate and bruse.
And rather like a Gyant monstruous.
Rather then once his burden to sustaine:
Rather then hunt still after shadowes vaine
Did rend the ratling skyes with flames of fouldring heat.
And all the dores to rattle round about;
That on his shield did rattle like to haile
He rau'd, he wept, he stampt, he lowd did cry,
But thousand enemies about vs raue,
With murmurous disdaine doth inly raue,
Doth rore at them in vaine, and with great terror raue.
Vnder a mightie rocke, gainst which do raue
Yet he therewith so felly still did raue,
That made him raue, like to a Lyon wood,
But be entombed in the rauen or the kight?
There shall a Rauen far from rising Sunne,
At all, that came within his rauenings,
Vpon a rauenous wolfe, and still did chaw
What euer thing does touch his rauenous pawes,
Whom rauenous hunger did thereto constraine:
And rend in peeces with his rauenous pawes,
And Cormoyrants, with birds of rauenous race,
That hath escaped from a rauenous beast,
Came riding on a Lion rauenous,
And harbour here in safety from those rauenous dogs.
A rauenous Wolfe amongst the scattered flockes.
Watching to driue the rauenous Wolfe away,
He rampt vpon him with his rauenous pawes,
Vpon whose stubborne neck, whereat he raues
He trayned was, till ryper yeares he raught,
That to the house of heauenly gods it raught,
He to him raught a dagger sharpe and keene,
And that so soone as ryper yeares he raught,
Sometimes she raught him stones, wherwith to smite,
Sir Guyons sword he lightly to him raught,
That from her shoulder to her heele downe raught,
Till ryper yeares he raught, and stronger stay:
Whiles his long legs nigh raught vnto the ground;
Soone to him raught, and fierce at him did ride,
He graunted: then the Faery quickly raught
Which faintly fluttring, scarce his helmet raught,
To reach the sea, ere she of him were raught:
And raught vnto her heeles; like sunny beames,
And when so of his hand the pledge she raught,
Another plant, that raught to wondrous hight,
Her golden cup to them for drinke she raught,
Sternly stept forth, and raught away his speare,
And raught downe to his waste, when vp he stood,
That ere vnto his hellish den he raught,
Enwouen was with gold, that raught full low a downe.
In which she noursled him, till yeares he raught,
Vntill the ripenesse of mans yeares he raught;
There her assayling fiercely fresh, he raught her
Vp to her ham, but when she list, it raught
Did stay her cruell hand, ere she her raught,
Eftsoones againe his axe he raught on hie,
In all her life, with long nayles ouer raught,
He ouer raught him, hauing long eschew'd
When Calidore these ruefull newes had raught,
Sir Calidore when thus he now had raught
Through which into his darke abisse all rauin fell.
For he liu'd all on rauin and on rape
Full of fell rauin and fierce greedinesse;
That would his rightfull rauine rend away:
With murdrous rauine, and deuouring might
They spoile and rauine without all remorse,
And meant to rauish her, that rather had to dy.
And rauished with rare impression in his sprite.
That with his melting sweetnesse rauished,
With such regard his sences rauished,
And in sweete rauishment pourd out her spright:
That he was rapt with double rauishment,
That weaker sence it could haue rauisht quight:
Was neuer hart so rauisht with delight,
And with her wondrous beautie rauisht quight,
At last quite rauisht with delight, to heare
All that her saw with wonder rauisht weare,
That I nigh rauisht with rare thoughts delight,
That raungd abroad to seeke aduentures wilde,
Who had more ioy to raunge the forrest wyde,
As she the woods with bow and shafts did raunge,
But what art thou, ï¿½ Ladie, which doest raunge
But ouer all the countrey she did raunge,
The land for sea, at randon there to raunge:
Whose wandring fancie after lust did raunge,
When he did raunge the wood for saluage game,
One day as he did raunge the fields abroad,
A teme of Dolphins raunged in aray,
All raunged in a ring, and dauncing in delight.
All they without were raunged in a ring,
Therein an hundred raunges weren pight,
With many raunges reard along the wall;
All set with yron teeth in raunges twaine,
Of all that raungeth in the forrest greene;
So now he raungeth through the world againe,
Raunging the forest wide on courser free,
Belphebe raunging in that forrest wide,
Yet shall it not her lockes for raunsome fro me free.
Vnder the foot of Rauran mossy hore,
Full of great lumpes of flesh and gobbets raw,
And all his sinews woxen weake and raw,
In which yet trickling bloud and gobbets raw
His cheeke bones raw, and eie-pits hollow grew,
A villaine to them came with scull all raw,
Her lips were like raw lether, pale and blew,
His rawbone armes, whose mighty brawned bowrs
His raw-bone cheekes through penurie and pine,
With hollow eyes and rawbone cheekes forspent,
Dimmed her former beauties shining ray,
A mayden Queene, that shone as Titans ray,
And face all tand with scorching sunny ray,
Like glauncing light of Phoebus brightest ray;
For so exceeding shone his glistring ray,
To passe, for succour from the scorching ray,
And the cleane waues with purple gore did ray;
In secret shadow from the sunny ray,
Early before the Morne with cremosin ray,
Such was the beautie and the shining ray,
Through influence of th'heauens fruitfull ray,
As doth the lilly fresh before the sunny ray.
Fresh shadowes, fit to shroud from sunny ray;
Ne euer euening saw, ne mornings ray,
And spoyling all her geares and goodly ray,
That flakes of fire, bright as the sunny ray,
And all the damzels of that towne in ray,
But enuies cloud still dimmeth vertues ray.
And from his face the filth that did it ray,
Like to the Euening starre adorn'd with deawy ray.
Like Phoebus face adornd with sunny rayes,
But all the day before the sunny rayes
Of the bright mettall, shyning like Sunne rayes;
That all the earth doest lighten with thy rayes,
by Strife is rayld vpon.
And a long bloudy riuer through them rayld,
And rayl'd and rag'd, till she had all her poyson spent.
Horribly then he gan to rage, and rayle,
Als when his brother saw the red bloud rayle
All carelesse of his taunt and bitter rayle,
Out of their brests, that streames of bloud did rayle
And rayle at them with grudgefull discontent,
Against the stones and trees did rayle anew,
And fouly rayle, with all she could inuent;
In vaine the Pagan bannes, and sweares, and rayles,
Shamefully at her rayling all the way,
And still amidst her rayling, she did pray,
Her bitter rayling and foule reuilement,
In stead of rest thou lendest rayling teares,
Reuiling me, and rayling as she lust,
He on himselfe had ta'en, and rayling rymes had sprad.
As those vnknightly raylings, which he spoke,
And in their steede for other rayment sought,
With locks all loose, and rayment all to rent;
The fields my food, my flocke my rayment breed;
With ruffled rayments, and faire blubbred face,
Then all the sonnes of these fiue brethren raynd
He left three sonnes, the which in order raynd,
Peace vniuersall rayn'd mongst men and beasts,
Through highest heauen with weaker hand to rayne;
Which mortall Princes wore, whiles they on earth did rayne.
from Brute to Vthers rayne.
Her sonne Sisillus after her did rayne,
Then afterwards he in his stead did rayne;
Thenceforth Aurelius peaceably did rayne,
After all these Elficleos did rayne,
And ouerruling him in his owne rayne,
But simple Truth did rayne, and was of all admyred.
Vnto the pallace, where their kings did rayne,
Of good king Meliogras which did rayne
To the long raynes, at her commaundement:
With raynes, or wonted rule, as well he knew.
The resty raynes, regarded now no more:
The house was raysd, and all that in did dwell;
And therein haue their mightie empire raysd,
Or hellish feend raysd vp through diuelish science.
And raysd him vp much stronger then before,
Haue rays'd this cruell warre and outrage fell,
The loft was raysd againe, that no man could it spie.
And to my tunes thy second tenor rayse,
Who first to rayse our house to honour did begin.
From whose two loynes thou afterwards did rayse
What heauenly Muse shall thy great honour rayse
To rayse a lyuing blame against the dead:
He tooke that Ladie, and her vp did rayse
More braue and noble knights haue raysed beene,
The hue and cry was raysed all about;
Wayling, and raysing pittifull vprore,
And heaped with so huge misfortunes, reach?
Then to him stepping, from his arme did reach
But through his boldnesse rather feare did reach,
That weaker wit of man could neuer reach,
Or what within his reach he euer drawes.
Bad on that Messenger rude hands to reach.
And lower part did reach to lowest Hell;
To reach the fruit, which grew vpon the brincke:
Far reach her mercies, and her prayses farre,
To reach, when euer he for ought did send;
The reach of men, through flight into fond mischief fell.
His wonder farre exceeded reasons reach,
And with her right the riper fruit did reach,
Then reasons reach, and oft hath wonders donne.
And reach into the house, that beares the stile
To reach the sea, ere she of him were raught:
The Troiane flames, and reach to heauens hight
As if his dayes were come to their last reach.
That one did reach, the other pusht away,
